whatIs.title: What is VHDL?
whatIs.description: VHDL (VHSIC Hardware Description Language) is a hardware description language used to model digital electronic systems.

history.title: History
history.description: Developed in the 1980s by the U.S. Department of Defense, it is now IEEE 1076 standard.

features.title: Features
features.description: Strongly typed, supports concurrency, allows simulation and synthesis of digital circuits.

entities.title: Entities and Architectures
entities.description: The entity defines the interface (input/output ports) and the architecture describes the internal behavior of the circuit.

signals.title: Signals and Variables
signals.description: Signals represent physical connections between components, while variables are used for temporary calculations within processes.

processes.title: Processes and Clock
processes.description: Processes are sequential blocks that execute when signals in the sensitivity list change, essential for synchronous logic.

dataTypes.title: Data Types
dataTypes.description: VHDL has native types (std_logic, integer, boolean) and allows creation of custom types to represent states and structures.

stateMachines.title: State Machines
stateMachines.description: FSMs (Finite State Machines) are fundamental for sequential control, implemented with processes and enumerated types.

hierarchy.title: Hierarchy and Components
hierarchy.description: Complex projects are divided into smaller components, creating modular and reusable hierarchy.

andGate.title: AND Gate
andGate.description: Create a 2-input logical AND gate. The output is '1' only when BOTH inputs are '1'.
instructions: Create an entity named 'porta_and' with 2 inputs (a, b) and 1 output (y)
Use the 'and' operator to combine the inputs: y <= a and b;
andGate.hint: The AND gate uses the 'and' operator. Remember: entity name is Port(...); end name; then architecture...
andGate.successMessage: Perfect! You created your first logic gate in VHDL!

orGate.title: OR Gate
orGate.description: Create a 2-input logical OR gate. The output is '1' when AT LEAST ONE input is '1'.
instructions: Create an entity named 'porta_or' with 2 inputs (a, b) and 1 output (y)
Use the 'or' operator to combine the inputs
orGate.hint: Similar to the AND gate, but use the 'or' operator instead of 'and'.
orGate.successMessage: Excellent! The OR gate is working correctly!

notGate.title: NOT Gate (Inverter)
notGate.description: Create a logical NOT gate. The output is always the INVERSE of the input.
instructions: Create an entity named 'porta_not' with 1 input (a) and 1 output (y)
Use the 'not' operator to invert the input
notGate.hint: The NOT operator is used like this: y <= not a;
notGate.successMessage: Great job! You've mastered the NOT operator!

mux.title: 2:1 Multiplexer
mux.description: Create a multiplexer that selects between 2 inputs based on a selection signal.
instructions: Create an entity with 2 data inputs (a, b), 1 selector (sel), and 1 output (y)
Use a conditional expression: y <= a when sel='0' else b;
When sel=0, output y receives 'a'. When sel=1, y receives 'b'
mux.hint: Use the structure: output <= input1 when condition else input2;
mux.successMessage: Fantastic! You've created a functional multiplexer!

halfAdder.title: Half Adder
halfAdder.description: Circuit that adds two bits, generating the sum (S) and carry out (C).
instructions: Create a 'half_adder' entity with inputs 'a' and 'b', outputs 's' (sum) and 'c' (carry)
The sum is: s <= a xor b;
The carry is: c <= a and b;
halfAdder.hint: Use XOR operator for the sum and AND for the carry. Remember: 1+1 = 10 in binary (sum=0, carry=1).
halfAdder.successMessage: Excellent! The Half Adder is the basis for more complex adders!

fullAdder.title: Full Adder
fullAdder.description: Adds three bits: a, b and carry_in, producing sum and carry_out. Base for multi-bit adders.
instructions: Create a 'full_adder' entity with inputs a, b, carry_in and outputs s, carry_out
Sum: s <= a xor b xor carry_in;
Carry out: carry_out <= (a and b) or (carry_in and (a xor b));
fullAdder.hint: The Full Adder can be built with two Half Adders. The carry_out formula combines multiple conditions with OR.
fullAdder.successMessage: Perfect! Full Adders are chained to create 8, 16, 32-bit adders!

decoder2to4.title: 2-to-4 Decoder
decoder2to4.description: Converts 2 input bits into 4 outputs, where only one output is '1' at a time.
instructions: Create a 'decoder_2to4' entity with 2-bit input (sel) and 4-bit output (y)
Use a process with case-when to map each input combination
decoder2to4.hint: Use case sel is ... when '00' => y <= '0001'; ... end case; inside a process.
decoder2to4.successMessage: Great! Decoders are essential for memory selection and multiplexing!

counter0to3.title: 0-3 Counter with Enable
counter0to3.description: 2-bit counter (0→1→2→3→0) that only counts when enable='1'.
instructions: Create a 'counter_0to3' entity with clock, reset, enable and count output (2 bits)
Use process with rising_edge(clock) for synchronous logic
If reset='1': count <= '00'
If enable='1': increment count (use numeric_std for conversion)
counter0to3.hint: Use library IEEE.NUMERIC_STD.ALL; and convert: count <= std_logic_vector(unsigned(count) + 1);
counter0to3.successMessage: Excellent! You've mastered sequential logic with enable!

tutorial.title: Step-by-Step Tutorial: BCD to 7-Segment Decoder
tutorial.subtitle: Learn to develop VHDL code step by step with real-time validation
tutorial.allCompleted: Congratulations! You've completed all tutorial steps!

feedback.error: ❌ Oops! The code isn't correct yet. Review the instructions and try again. Click 'Show Hint' if you need help.

steps.title: Step 1: Entity Declaration
steps.description: Let's start by declaring the entity for our BCD to 7-segment display decoder.
steps.instruction: Complete the code by declaring the input and output ports. The input should be a 4-bit vector (BCD) and the output should be a 7-bit vector (segments).
steps.hint: Use 'std_logic_vector' for vectors. Format: (3 downto 0) for 4 bits and (6 downto 0) for 7 bits.
steps.successMessage: ✅ Perfect! You correctly declared the entity with input and output ports.

steps.title: Step 2: Starting the Architecture
steps.description: Now let's create the architecture that implements the decoder logic.
steps.instruction: Declare the 'behavioral' architecture and start the process sensitive to the 'entrada' signal.
steps.hint: Use 'architecture behavioral of bcd_7seg is' and then 'process(entrada)'.
steps.successMessage: ✅ Excellent! The architecture and process structure is correct.

steps.title: Step 3: Case Structure
steps.description: Inside the process, we'll use a 'case' structure to map each BCD input to corresponding segments.
steps.instruction: Add the 'case' structure that analyzes the 'entrada' value and complete the first 3 numbers (0, 1 and 2).
steps.hint: Format: case entrada is when "0000" => segmentos <= "1111110"; -- For number 0
steps.successMessage: ✅ Very good! You correctly mapped numbers 0, 1 and 2. Keep it up!

steps.title: Step 4: Completing Numbers 3-6
steps.description: Let's add more numbers to our decoder.
steps.instruction: Complete the mapping for numbers 3, 4, 5 and 6.
steps.successMessage: ✅ Fantastic! Only the last numbers left.

steps.title: Step 5: Finishing with 7, 8 and 9
steps.description: Final step! Let's complete the decoder with the remaining numbers.
steps.instruction: Complete the mapping for numbers 7, 8 and 9.
steps.successMessage: 🎉 Congratulations! You completed the BCD to 7-segment display decoder!
